The Medina Azahara was a vast palace complex built by the most powerful of the Moorish rulers, Abd-ar-Rahman III, to consolidate his rule as Caliph over previously Umayyad Spain. According to Legend, it was named after Abd-ar-Rahman's favourite concubine: Azahara. A few miles from the center of Cordoba, the palace served as the de facto capital of Muslim Iberia. Built beginning in 936 CE, the small city in itself included magnificent reception halls, opulent pavillions and spacious gardens that attracted the poets and artists of Al-Andalus.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] In 1010, the palace was sacked during a civil war and as a result, abandoned. New rulers recycled many of it's ruins to erect buildings far away.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Starting in 1910, the remnants of the vast complex were excavated. Since then, only 10% of the 277 acres have been uncovered, though this includes the central part of Medina Azahara.

The internationally renowned Mosque-Cathedral of Cordoba is built on the site of a previous Visigothic Church. After the Islamic conquest of the Visigothic Spain, the building was divided between Christians and Muslims. When Abd-ar-Rahman I became the new emir in 750 CE, he purchased the Christian half and built a mosque to rival those of Damascus, Baghdad and Jerusalem. Over the course of future Emirs and Caliphs, the mosque was changed and expanded till Cordoba fell to the rulers of Castile, who subsequently converted it into a cathedral.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Mosque-Cathedral of Cordoba is famous for its long rows of arches and the richly gilded mihrab. Spotless white marble from nearby quarries was brought in for the innumerable columns. The Mosque-Cathedral has 20 doors in total, all from throughout it's history.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Since the early 2000s, Spanish Muslims have lobbied the Roman Catholic Church to allow them to pray in the building. The Vatican and Spanish churches have opposed this move. Others have called for it to be converted into a museum, similar to the Hagia Sophia in Istanbul.
